name: cyanoacetic acid production | cyanoacetic acid | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/58/documentation

The process “cyanoacetic acid, at plant, RER” is modelled for the production of cyanoacetic acid from chloroacetic acid in Europe. Raw materials are modelled with a stoechiometric calculation. Emissions are estimated. Energy consumptions, infrastructure and transports are calculated with standard values.;Cyanoacetic acid (C3H3NO2; CAS 372-09-8) forms colourless, hygroscopic crystals, that undergo decarboxylation above 160 °C to give acetonitrile. The compound has a dissociation constant of 3.65 × 10–3 in water (25 °C) and dissolves readily in water, but is only moderately soluble in ethanol, and sparingly in benzene. The industrially most important cyanoacetate is ethyl cyanoacetate, followed by the methyl ester. Both esters are colourless liquids, which are miscible with ethanol and diethyl ether but insoluble in water. Cyanoacetic acid and the cyanoacetates are produced by the same route (and often in the same plant) as the malonates by cyanidation of sodium chloroacetate followed by acidification of the sodium cyanoacetate solution. Cyanoacetic acid is isolated by extraction with an organic solvent and evaporation of the solvent, whereas the cyanoacetates are obtained by mineral acid-catalyzed esterification with subsequent azeotropic removal of water. Major byproducts are malonates and succinates. A process variation involves interchange of the cyanidation and esterification steps. In this case, however, the formation of the side product dimethyl or diethyl 2-cyanosuccinate is difficult to suppress. In order to avoid the isolation, most of the cyanoacetic acid outlets are produced directly from solution.;The world's largest cyanoacetate plant was brought on stream in 1987 in Mobile (Alabama) by Hüls. The annual production capacity of this plant was later expanded to 8000 t.;Alternative methods for the preparation of cyanoacetic acid involve the carboxylation of acetonitrile and the oxidation of partially oxidized propionitriles. Other methods for the preparation of cyanoacetates include the cleavage of cyanoacetaldehyde dimethyl acetal, formed by a palladium-catalyzed oxidation of acrylonitrile, the alkoxycarbonylation of chloroacetonitrile and pyrolysis of 3,3′-bisisoxazole in the presence of an alcohol. However, none of these processes have been used industrially.;;The most important application of cyanoacetates is in the field of adhesives. Knoevenagel reaction of alkyl cyanoacetates with formaldehyde affords α-cyanoacrylates, which are stable under exclusion of air but polymerize rapidly to polycyanoacrylates after application on a surface even at room temperature. This polymerization is reversible on heating and the monomer can be formed back and subsequently polymerized again by traces of moisture. Esters of higher alcohols, such as 1-butanol, are also employed.;Otherwise, cyanoacetates are used for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, dyes, and UV absorbers. For many applications cyanoacetic acid, cyanoacetates, or cyanoacetamide can be used alternatively. Caffeine (R = CH3) is synthesized from theophylline (R = H), which is accessible in several steps from cyanoacetic acid and 1,3-dimethylurea. The traded cyanoacetic acid is mainly used for the production of the fungicide cymoxanil and the cough remedy dextromethorphan.;;Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Heck T., Hellweg S., Hischier R., Nemecek T., Rebitzer G. and Spielmann M. (2007) Overview and Methodology. Final report ecoinvent v2.0 No. 1. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.org.;;Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen as pdf-File under: http://www.gendorf.de/pdf/umwelterklaerung2000.pdf;;Kim 2003: Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle as-sessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003;;Harald Strittmatter, Stefan Hildbrand, Peter Pollak: Malonic Acid and Derivatives. Published online: 2007. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: DOI: 10.1002/14356007.a16_063.pub2;;;The most important application of cyanoacetates is in the field of adhesives. Knoevenagel reaction of alkyl cyanoacetates with formaldehyde affords α-cyanoacrylates 16, which are stable under exclusion of air but polymerize rapidly to polycyanoacrylates 17 after application on a surface even at room temperature. This polymerization is reversible on heating and the monomer can be formed back and subsequently polymerized again by traces of moisture. Esters of higher alcohols, such as 1-butanol, are also employed.;Otherwise, cyanoacetates are used for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, dyes, and UV absorbers. For many applications cyanoacetic acid, cyanoacetates, or cyanoacetamide can be used alternatively. Caffeine (R = CH3) is synthesized from theophylline (R = H), which is accessible in several steps from cyanoacetic acid and 1,3-dimethylurea. The traded cyanoacetic acid is mainly used for the production of the fungicide cymoxanil and the cough remedy dextromethorphan.;The most important application of cyanoacetates is in the field of adhesives. Knoevenagel reaction of alkyl cyanoacetates with formaldehyde affords α-cyanoacrylates, which are stable under exclusion of air but polymerize rapidly to polycyanoacrylates after application on a surface even at room temperature. This polymerization is reversible on heating and the monomer can be formed back and subsequently polymerized again by traces of moisture. Esters of higher alcohols, such as 1-butanol, are also employed.;Otherwise, cyanoacetates are used for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, dyes, and UV absorber. For many applications cyanoacetic acid, cyanoacetates, or cyanoacetamide (can be used alternatively. Caffeine (R = CH3) is synthesized from theophylline (R = H), which is accessible in several steps from cyanoacetic acid and 1,3-dimethylurea. The traded cyanoacetic acid is mainly used for the production of the fungicide cymoxanil and the cough remedy dextromethorphan.

flow.name: cyanoacetic acid
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description: The remaining amount of unreacted chloroacetic acid is assumed to leave the production process with the waste water. Further it was assumed that this wastewater is treated in a internal wastewater plant. The removal efficiency for chloroacetic acid is assumed with 90%.

The values for COD, BOD, TOC, DOC, and AOX used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of chloroacetic acid in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.

As there was no data available for the production of cyanoacetic acid, the values for the consumption of chloroacetic acid and hydrogen cycanide are calculated with an assumed yield of 95 % (Frischknecht et al. 2007).
EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description:
No information was readily available about infrastructure and land-use of cyanoacetic acid production plants. Therefore, in this study, the infrastructure is estimated based on the module "chemical plant, organics". This module assumes a built area of about 4.2 ha, an average output of 50'000 t/a, and plant life of fifty years. For this study, the estimated value is 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.
EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description: The values for COD, BOD, TOC, DOC, and AOX used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of chloroacetic acid in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of river water in the years 2015-2019 was 22000820 t per year. However, since the cooling water is modelled as an input, the amount of river water was adjusted to avoid double counting. 55% of the input amount of cooling water was deducted from the amount of river water, as that is the share of river water versus well water. This equals 0.00096543 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. To determine the emissions of water to air, the difference of all water inputs (from river, well, tap water and cooling) and outputs (wastewater, emissions to water) was calculated. The average ouput of water to air in the years 2015-2019 was 3620444 m3 per year. This equals 0.00147 m3/kg chemical produced. For more information on the other water exchanges please consult the respective exchange comment.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average amount of cooling water released in the years 2015-2019 was 34408800 t per year. It was assumed that 5% of the cooling water was emitted to air during its use, therefore, to calculate the input of cooling water, the output value reported by GENDORF was scaled up by the factor 1/0.95. This equals 0.014707 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Estimation from the emission of chloroacetic acid.

There was no data available on process emissions to air for the production. As approximation the air emissions occurring from the purge vent, the distillation vent and fugitive emission sources were estimated to 0.2% of the Chloroacetic acid input.

exchanges.description: The values for COD, BOD, TOC, DOC, and AOX used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of chloroacetic acid in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average ouput of wastewater going to an external wastewater treatment plant in the years 2015-2019 was 5608 m3 per year. This equals 0.000002277 m3/kg chemical produced.

Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of well water in the years 2015-2019 was 18607480 t per year. This equals 0.00081652 m3/kg chemical produced.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The amount of water released back to the environment consists of the sum of the amount of process water treated in the internal WWTP that is then released back to the environment and the amount of cooling water released back to the environment. The average ouput of  the internal WWTP in the years 2015-2019 was 2628800 m3 and that of cooling water released back to the environment was 34408800 m3. This gives a yearly average of 37037600 m3 emissions of water to water. This equals 0.01504 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
The unreacted hydrogen cyanide is considered to be burned. The carbon contained in the burned hydrogen cyanide and the removed chloroacetic acid is accounted as CO2 emissions to air.
